title: Practice Challenge
description: Apply what you've learned in this interactive coding challenge.
instructions:
Create a validation library using source-generated regex!

1. Create a partial class 'InputValidators' with generated regex methods:
   - CreditCard: 16 digits (with optional dashes/spaces every 4)
   - PostalCode: 5 digits or 5+4 format (12345 or 12345-6789)
   - Username: 3-20 alphanumeric characters, underscores allowed
   - StrongPassword: At least 8 chars, must have upper, lower, digit, special

2. Create a Validate() method that tests each pattern

3. Test with sample valid and invalid inputs

4. Print results showing which validations pass/fail

Use [GeneratedRegex] attribute for AOT compatibility!

hints.text: [GeneratedRegex(@"pattern")] on a partial static method. The @ allows backslashes without escaping.
Lookaheads for password: (?=.*[a-z]) means 'somewhere has lowercase'. Stack multiple lookaheads for AND logic.
Optional groups: (-\d{4})? matches dash + 4 digits, or nothing. The ? makes it optional.
Character class [-\s] matches dash or whitespace. Use for flexible separators in credit cards.
Quantifiers: {3,20} means 3 to 20 occurrences. {8,} means 8 or more.

commonMistakes.mistake: Making the method non-static or non-partial
commonMistakes.consequence: [GeneratedRegex] requires 'static partial' method signature. Otherwise generator ignores it!
commonMistakes.correction: public static partial Regex MethodName(); - both static AND partial required.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using Regex.Match instead of generated method
commonMistakes.consequence: Regex.Match(input, pattern) compiles pattern at runtime - not AOT compatible!
commonMistakes.correction: Call the generated method: MyRegex().IsMatch(input) uses precompiled pattern.

commonMistakes.consequence: Pattern [a-z]+ might need \[ or \. for literal brackets/dots. Wrong escaping = wrong matches.
commonMistakes.correction: Use @ verbatim strings: @"\d+" - one backslash in the pattern. Or regular: "\\d+" - escaped backslash.

commonMistakes.consequence: Regex with many lookaheads can be slow or hit catastrophic backtracking.
commonMistakes.correction: Keep it simple, or validate in steps: check length, then check each requirement separately.
